document_data.mainbody: '''The Forest of Tethir''', also known as '''Wealdath''', and on the [[Sword Coast]] and one of the largest in all of [[Faer√ªn]]. Some scholars were of the opinion that the forest was the "single most important thing" that set the culture of [[Tethyr]].
document_data.Etymology:
The forest was named after the epic [[Elf|elven]] hero [[Tethir (hero)|Tethir]], The name of the forest is always spelled with an "i", while the name of the country is spelled with a "y",

The elves also called the forest "Wealdath", which means "unspoiled woods" in [[Elven language|Elvish]].

After [[1370 DR]], the official name of the forest was made Wealdath by the government of Tethyr, though the people of [[Amn]] still called it the Forest of Tethir.

Geography.Flora & Fauna:
[[File:Forest of Tethir.png|thumb|''Forest of Tethir's interior.''|291x291px]]
A large yet not particularly dense wood—unless one was at least ten miles from the borders where the trees grew far thicker—the trees of Tethir were very large and old, their wide trunks rising to a great height above. Many of the trees along the [[Trade Way]] were transplanted there after the fall of [[Myth Drannor]] by the elven refugees of [[Cormanthor]]. Most of the trees were evergreens, though there were many other kinds as well, including cedar, [[Duskwood (tree)|duskwood]], maple, and oak.

Smaller plants, such as berry bushes, ivy, and flowering plants also thrived here, and the streams and ponds were full of lilies.

The Forest of Tethir was full of a plethora of monsters—[[ankheg]]s, [[basilisk]]s, [[bloodthorn]]s, [[bulette]]s, [[choke creeper]]s, [[giant spider]]s, [[manticore]]s, [[owlbear]]s, [[stirge]]s, and [[wyvern]]s. Packs of [[Wolf|wolves]] were also common, and the trees were home to an abundant variety of birds and wild game. On the Peninsula, the moist conditions meant that there were many fungi, molds, and slimes to be found.

document_data.Government: Officially, with the start of Queen [[Zaranda Star|Zaranda]]'s reign, the forest was divided into two [[wikipedia:en:Duchy|duchies]], [[Noromath]] in the west and [[Durmista]] in the east, as a major part of the [[Corsairs' Sea|Principality of the Corsairs' Sea]]. Duke [[Allain Kevanarial|Allain "Foxfire" Kevanarial]] was the official ruler of Normath, while [[Mirthal Aendryr]] officially led Durmista.
document_data.Religion: Worship of both [[Eldath]] and [[Silvanus]] was very popular among those living near and within the borders of the forest, even among the elves.

Notable Locations.[[Brost]]: This small trading post was on the northern edge of the forest and connected to the [[Tethir Road]] by a small trail.
Notable Locations.[[The Eight's Tree]]: This was the secret stronghold of the [[Company of Eight]].
Notable Locations.[[Mosstone]]: This town was located along the [[Trade Way]] just south of the forest.
Notable Locations.[[Myth Rhynn]]: This ancient elven necropolis lay in the forest. Around [[1374 DR]], the [[Vel'Nikeryma]] had an interest in restoring its [[mythal]].
Notable Locations.[[Suldanessellar]]: This elven city was built high above the ground in the trees.

document_data.Inhabitants:
The elves of the Wealdath were divided into two major tribes—the [[Elmanesse]] and the [[Suldusk]]. The Elmanesse lived in a large expanse of woods east of the Trade Way, in Noromath; the Suldusk lived in the southeastern reaches.

[[Lythari]], elven shapeshifters, had at least four [[portal]]s in the forest that led to their plane, a peaceful subdimension.

In [[1479 DR]], two cells of the [[Eldreth Veluuthra]] operated in the forest, one for each of the Elmanesse and Suldusk elven tribes. The cells aimed to protect their tribal lands from [[human]]s. Both tribes were closely allied with Tethyr due to the royal family's agreement to respect the elven forest.

Good-aligned [[drow]] were also reported to live in the Forest of Tethir.

Apart from elves, there were many [[fey]] creatures and monster races making their homes among the trees, among them: [[brownie]]s, [[centaur]]s, [[dryad]]s, [[satyr]]s, [[sprite]]s, [[bugbear]]s, [[gnoll]]s, [[hobgoblin]]s, [[kobold]]s, [[leprechaun]]s, [[Lycanthropy|lycanthropes]], [[ogre]]s, [[orc]]s, [[treant]]s, [[troll]]s, [[atomie]]s, [[green hag]]s, and [[norker]]s.

Bandits maintained several bases within the borders of the forest, adding to the danger already present from the high population of monsters. Pirates from the [[Nelanther Isles]] would often land on the Peninsula to cut down timber for their ships.

The forest was also used as a base for the Company of Eight, the famous adventuring group, during the [[Tethyrian Interregnum]].

The forest was also home to several dragons—at least two [[green dragon]]s ([[Linussaxannol]] and [[Buchembrallor]]) and a [[Gold dragon|gold]] and a [[Bronze dragon|bronze]] ([[Garlokantha]] and [[Arellaxerrontoal]]). [[White dragon]]s used to live in the forest, but by 1370 DR, these lairs were occupied by [[goblinoid]] tribes.
document_data.History:
The Forest of Tethir was once a part of a single massive forest covering the modern Lands of Intrigue. The elves named this forest kingdom [[Keltormir]]. Wars with [[dragon]]s and [[giant]]s led to the destruction of great swaths of forest and split Keltomir into the [[Snakewood]], [[Shilmista]], the [[Forest of Mir]], and the Forest of Tethir. This was known as the [[First Tethirift]]. The war was ended when the great hero Tethir sacrificed his own life and killed two great [[red dragon]]s.

The forest was originally home to the Suldusk, [[Tethir (clan)|Tethir]], and [[Stilmyst]] clans.

Enmity between the humans of Tethyr and the elves of Tethir rose about 85 years before the [[DR|Dalereckoning]], when the humans from [[Clan Karlag]] began foresting parts of the forest to create beaches for their shipyards. While he was trying to negotiate peace between the elves and the human clans, one of the Karlag clansmen murdered the crown prince of Tethyr, [[Garynor Ithal II]]. Clan Karlag was outcast forevermore. The clear-cut region of the forest later became the path the Trade Way would take.

In the tenth century [[DR]], forest fires burned down many of the trees of the central forest, but this ended up creating peaceful groves and opportunities for younger trees to flourish.

In the [[1364 DR|Year of the Wave, 1364 DR]], a mercenary named [[Bunlap]] ran a logging operation in the eastern part of the forest, and his men killed and enslaved many elves. Bunlap was stopped by the efforts of [[Arilyn Moonblade]], who had been sent from [[Evermeet]]. The incident was known as the [[Tethir Conflicts]].

Before the Tethyrian civil war, [[demihuman]]s were treated poorly by the humans of Tethyr, and they had no rights. The elves, especially, were driven deep into the forest. which was blamed on the elves.) When the [[Lions' Dynasty]] was overthrown and the Interregnum began, the elves formed their own Elven Council and considered the Forest of Tethir its own sovereign nation.

After the Interregnum, Queen Zaranda made peace with the elves of the forest and sought to integrate them into politics.
document_data.Rumors and Legends:
The Forest of Tethir was feared by humans for generations, ever since the death of King Errilam.

In [[1357 DR]], there was talk about a powerful [[archdevil]] gathering evil forces to himself in the midst of the forest.
